arch:property.oc:show_val: The length and breadth of the trench.
Construction of the early steps with the landing and threshold into Room 1.
1.02 m north south-by-1.40 m east west.

Locus 1 consists of 8 smoothed limestone pavers that made up the exposed portion of the landing of the earlier Propylaeum staircase. They were generally in good condition, with some cracking. The pavers were 0.07 m thick at their thickest point, however their underside had been beveled to allow them to be set and held in place by the fine soil/dust matrix they were laid in (Locus 2) (See Drawing #). The paver measured 0.83 m in length-by-0.365 m in width. They appear to have been built at the same time as and as part of the same architectural plan as the earlier Propylaeum Steps and the threshold into the room to the west.

Phase VI: Late Nabataean ca. 106 CE period of minor collapse and repairs. Collapse of the south gallery cryptoportici of the Propylaeum East and West. Signs of Roman aggression noted particularly in the north gallery of the Propylaeum West, which was used as a repository for ballista balls against threatening forces.
